posts.post_content:
Increasing the CMC of a [Phyrexian Negator](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Phyrexian Negator) by one apparently allows changing his drawback into an equally big advantage...given of course that you change the color of the expansion symbol to orange, too.  
  
Red and green can suck on that one. *(Or rather, their side will get completely sucked through this card.)*  
Imo this dude at least shouldn't be able to block, so players could try to stomp their mono-black opponent over before he does...  
  
Not even saying it's overpowered. Just not that type of Mythic Rare i like.   
  
Amazing flavor thoguh.
posts.html:

posts.post_content: Anybody that doesn't like this guy is holding out because they love old power and old cards. It is nice to see a new mover and a shaker out on the battlefield. I've played with this, it is powerful, yet it can also be defeated. Black has always had crazy big horrors or demons or whatever that had to be dealt with immediately. I think it even has a relatively classic feel and look on the battlefield, especially when you see the fear in the opponents eyes... third turn, nice; second turn, awesome; first turn, Obliterator!!!

posts.post_content:
I've butted heads with this guy in 4 draft games (NMS/MBS/SOM). Each game my opponent went swamp, swamp, swamp, swamp, Phyrexian Obliterator. Had no answers. Was handily defeated.  
  
I've drafted this card twice. First time I drafted him I tried to build mono black around him and ended up with a pretty crummy deck because of it. Never even got him onto the board. Second time I drafted him I won the draft but he didn't even make my deck, even though I had 2 ragers, grim affliction and 2 morbid plunders. He's the hardest thing to cast in limited.

posts.post_content:
Lateralis0ne,
  
   
First off, assuming my age before forming a proper argument shows me that you're clearly younger than I am. Secondly, you don't actually FORM a proper argument. You speak of balance, then, and I quote, call the card, "crazy-powerful." There is no balance when certain colors gain cards on incredible, unbalanced strength. Look at Jace. Look at Stoneforge. The developers of Magic banned those cards because they powered up cards far too much and released them into the public without realizing the consequences. Here is a quote from MTG's R&D on the topic of overpowered cards:
  
   
"Everyone agrees that innovation is a Very Good Thing and thus we should be constantly pushing the envelope. Well, if we're constantly pushing the envelope and striving to come up with cool new weird and wacky cards, then occasionally we're going to make a mistake." - Randy Buehler
  
   
Cards like this are not only a problem for non-black players, but for everyone. People defending this card make a va... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

posts.post_content:
To deal with this you need:  
Deathtouch  
Non-damage removal (exile, destroy, -X/-X, into-library, bounce)  
Damage redirection (lawl)  
Ablative Permanents or Health (I.E. don't deal with it)  
Mind control  
Temporary Mind Control (red)  
Stifle  
Creature becomes X/Y and loses all abilities  
Counters  
Abilities that do any of the above  
Maybe more stuff.  
  
  
After reading my old comment I've realized that the Mirran side was mostly red/white. Red being terrible against this thing ends up making much more sense flavor-wise when you realize that red is the actual enemy of this card. Also interesting to note, it's good even against double or first strike.   
  
That said,  
@Cheza  
I have like.. 3 Demon tribal decks because the demons are so awesome. I utilize everything from mass reanimation/dredge (like opening hell itself to piss forth demons) to the morph demons to hardcast them super early, to simply using the demons who come with free mass-removal (havoc, carnifex, pestilence, reiver.) When it comes to c... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
